meanings.definition: To shorten by omissions while retaining the basic contents
meanings.sent1: She was abridging the story to make it shorter for the children.
meanings.sent2: The editor was abridging the article to fit it on one page.
meanings.sent3: By abridging the recipe, she accidentally left out a key ingredient.
meanings.sent4: His speech was like abridging a novel into a short story, losing some details.
meanings.sent5: The teacher explained how abridging a text can help focus on the main points.

meanings.definition: To reduce in scope or extent
meanings.sent1: The company was abridging its operations to save costs.
meanings.sent2: They were abridging the project timeline to meet the deadline.
meanings.sent3: The magician's trick involved abridging the length of the rope without cutting it.
meanings.sent4: The storm was abridging the once vast landscape into a small island.
meanings.sent5: Abridging the number of characters in the play made it more concise.

meanings.sent1: The new law was abridging the rights of the citizens.
meanings.sent2: The budget cuts were abridging the resources available for research.
meanings.sent3: His attempt to abridge the opponent's argument only made it stronger.
meanings.sent4: The fog was abridging the visibility on the road, causing accidents.
meanings.sent5: Abridging the time allocated for the presentation made it rushed and less effective.
